title: How can we understand 'another gospel' in its historical context? - Quora

response.answer_text: So I apply my English major skills and read this as a single sentence: I marvel that ye are so soon removed from him that called you into the grace of Christ unto another gospel: which is not another; but there be some that trouble you, and would pervert the gospel of Christ. I bolded these sections because they are grammatically connected: he’s telling the Galatians, effectively, “I preached the gospel of Christ to you and as soon as I left, you’re following someone preaching a corruption of that gospel! What gives?” Paul is a fine writer, but, wordy, with lots of interpolated thoughts in a kind of “stream of consciousness” sort of way. Sometimes, it helps to parse out the message from the rest of those interpolations. Doing so here gives us the idea that, when Paul left the Galatians, someone(s) came along and “perverted” the gospel he’d taught and was leading the church there astray. And what was the wayward teaching? Paul—again, taking the long route through a chapter and a half of exposition—gets there in chapter 3: O foolish Galatians, who hath bewitched you, that ye should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth, crucified among you?This only would I learn of you, Received ye the Spirit by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith? Are ye so foolish? having begun in the Spirit, are ye now made perfect by the flesh? So the question here is “Are we saved through faith in Christ, or through obedience to the Mosaic law?” Paul, explaining that he was converted from the “saved by obedience to the law” to the “saved through the grace of Christ,” goes on to make clear (through example after example) that the law was “dead” without the Atonement of Christ, because the entire law was pointing to the Atonement of Christ. One can almost hear his frustrated thoughts: “Do you not see that the burnt offerings were in similitude of the offering of God’s own son? How do you not see that?” Going back to Chapter 2, we read about Paul’s discussion with Peter about requiring would-be Christians to obey the Jewish traditions. Ultimately, Paul prevailed in the thinking that, since Peter was allowing Gentiles to be baptised (after the Cornelius revelation), requiring them to become Jews first (through circumcision and other religious traditions) made no sense, even though it was, technically, the same gospel of Christ. This is the “other gospel” that Paul was directly referring to, though indirectly, he’s also addressing any other spurious claims by anyone else coming in the name of Christ. As a member of a church that many see as heretical, I get this thrown in my face a lot, and I understand why. But Paul warns us as well not to let confirmation bias guide our choices on this matter, but to ask God and take instruction from the Spirit, not just men, which, as Jesus taught, is how we shall know the truth.

This is the verse in question. Gal 1:8 But though we, or an angel from heaven, preach any other gospel unto you than that which we have preached unto you, let him be accursed. The gospel preached was that Jesus was the Son of God and that only through Christ can one be saved. Any other gospel is false. "For there is one God and one mediator between God and mankind, the man Christ Jesus," 1 Timothy 2:5
